ground.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: A raised platform stood two metres off the ground.
The air raids were followed by military action on the ground (=on land).
ground troops (=soldiers who fight on land)
The leaves were slowly fluttering to the ground.
He lay on the ground and stared up at the sky.
At night, badgers feed above ground.
These youngsters work 70 metres below ground level.
ground.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the soil on and under the surface of the Earth
ground.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Dig the ground over in the autumn.
Plant the seeds 2 cm deep in the ground.
The ground was dry, far too dry for growing corn.
ground.translation[0].definitions[2].def: an area of land without buildings, fences, woods etc
ground.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The landscape is a mixture of open ground and woodland.
They were standing on the waste ground (=land in a town that is not being used) behind the car park.
ground.translation[0].definitions[3].def: an area of land or sea that is used for a particular purpose
ground.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: These fields served as a hunting ground for the local people.
The rivers are used as dumping grounds for industrial waste.
He is buried in sacred ground.
ground.translation[0].definitions[4].def: the land or gardens surrounding a large building
ground.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: We decided to take a stroll in the hotel grounds.
ground.translation[0].definitions[5].def: a subject or area of knowledge
ground.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: At meetings, we just keep going over the same ground (=talking about the same things).
His latest movie looks set to break new ground (=introduce new and exciting ideas).
In his latest book, McManus returns to more familiar ground.
ground.translation[0].definitions[6].def: a general opinion or set of attitudes
ground.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: Often parents and teenagers find they have little common ground (=they do not share the same attitudes etc).
Both parties are battling to occupy the centre ground.
Careful, Laura. You could be treading on dangerous ground (=expressing opinions etc that might offend someone).
Each side was unwilling to give ground (=change their opinion).
ground.translation[0].definitions[7].def: the place where a particular sport is played
ground.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: It’s their first defeat at their home ground (=the ground that belongs to a particular team) all season.
ground.translation[0].definitions[8].def: a wire that connects a piece of electrical equipment to the ground for safety
ground.translation[0].definitions[9].def: the colour used as the background for a design
ground.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: the ground
the surface of the Earth, or the soil on its surface
He collapsed and fell to the ground.
The ground was wet and muddy.
the ocean/forest/cave etc floor
the ground at the bottom of the ocean, a forest, a cave etc
Many wonderful creatures live on the ocean floor.
used when talking about an area of ground that is owned by someone, or is used for an activity. Also used when talking about the part of the Earth’s surface that is not covered with water
His family owns a lot of land.
agricultural land
She got off the ferry, happy to be back on dry land.
terrain
a type of land – used when talking about how easy an area of land is to cross, and whether it is rocky, flat etc
The Land Rover is built to go over rough terrain.
The terrain gets flatter when you go further south.
earth/soil
the substance that plants grow in
The vegetables were still covered in black soil.
mud
wet earth
Your shoes are covered in mud.
ground.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to stop an aircraft or pilot from flying
ground.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: All planes are grounded until the fog clears.
ground.translation[1].definitions[0].not: Ground is usually passive in this meaning
ground.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if you ground a boat or if it grounds, it hits the bottom of the sea so that it cannot move
ground.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Both boats grounded on a mud bank.
ground.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to stop a child going out with their friends as a punishment for behaving badly
ground.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: I got home at 2 am and Dad grounded me on the spot.
ground.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to make a piece of electrical equipment safe by connecting it to the ground with a wire
ground.translation[2].definitions[0].def: ground coffee or nuts have been broken up into powder or very small pieces, using a special machine
ground.translation[3].definitions[0].def: the past tense and past participle of grind1
ground.translation[4].definitions[0].def: a reason, often a legal or official one, for doing or believing something
ground.translation[4].definitions[0].exa: There are grounds for optimism that the slump in the housing market may end.
Are there grounds for dismissing him?
The factory was closed on health and safety grounds.
ground.translation[4].definitions[1].def: to get an advantage or to rise in price
ground.translation[4].definitions[1].exa: The dollar gained ground against sterling.
ground.translation[4].definitions[2].def: to lose an advantage or to fall in price
ground.translation[4].definitions[2].exa: Prices were lower across the board, with nearly all blue-chip stocks losing ground.
ground.translation[4].definitions[3].def: if a plan, business idea etc gets off the ground, it gets started or it starts to be successful
ground.translation[4].definitions[3].exa: This fund is intended to help new projects get off the ground.
ground.translation[4].definitions[4].def: to do something completely new that no one has ever done before or discover something new about a subject
ground.translation[4].definitions[4].exa: Our scientists are breaking new ground in AIDS research.
ground.translation[5].definitions[0].def: to be based on a particular idea, principle etc
ground.translation[5].definitions[0].exa: His fiscal strategy is firmly grounded in Keynesian economics.
